ResponseText: "Kind of privacy"? I'm not certain what you mean. Several aspects of personal life have been consistently part of privacy and have been protected by SCOTUS. For example: Loving v. Virginia . If not found within the Fourteenth Amendment's liberty clause and the implicit right to privacy, where would the basis for the decision be found that the State could not infringe upon a person's right to marry another of a different race? And since Loving, the Supreme Court has consistently held that the personal rights recognized in the case are protected by the right to privacy. In Carey v. Population Services (involving the right to contraception) and Zablocki v. Redhail (involving the right to marry), the Supreme Court held: While the outer limits of this aspect of privacy have not been marked by the Court, it is clear that among the decisions that an individual may make without unjustified government interference are personal decisions relating to marriage, Loving v. Virginia ; procreation, Skinner v. Oklahoma ex rel. Williamson ; contraception, Eisenstadt v. Baird ; family relationships, Prince v. Massachusetts [and] Meyer v. Nebraska . Procreation, conception, marriage, family life. All of these reasonably and rationally relate to the decision whether or not to terminate your pregnancy. It absolutely flows naturally with other protected areas of private life. Just looking at the two cases of Griswold v. Connecticut and Eisenstadt v. Baird , right to contraception cases, whether or not you have a child is a personal and private decision constitutionally protected from governmental interference. In Eisenstadt v. Baird , the Court extended the marital right to privacy in Griswold to unmarried individuals and explained that: if the right to privacy means anything, it is the right of an individual, married or single, to be free from unwarranted governmental intrusion into matters so fundamentally affecting a person as the decision whether to bear or beget a child. All of these necessarily include the freedom to decide whether or not to terminate the pregnancy.

QuoteText: How is it that you can legally kill a burglar that invades your house, however for some reason when something invades your body you have no right to kill it?
ResponseText: You can only legally kill a burglar if you have good reason to believe that your life is in danger. Should you arrive one day at your house and discover a burglar who clearly poses no threat to your person, you may not legally kill him though he walk out with all your earthly possessions. Yes, the burglar may be infringing upon your liberty, but you may not kill him because of that. If you must analogize it to the burglar, than it would apply this way. Most pro-life people agree that abortions that are necessary to save the mother's life are acceptable. What most pro-lifers do not agree with is that abortion is acceptable in situations where only a person's liberty or property might be infringed, but where it would not be necessary to save her life.

QuoteText: So, too, with respect to liberty. The Constitution does not explicitly give any the right to liberty; it merely states that the State cannot take away your liberty without Due Process. ResponseText: Right, that's the point. While the language is similar in both cases, the two rights (not to be deprived of liberty and not to be deprived of life) do not apply equally in this issue. While the woman's liberty is protected by the Constitution, the life of the fetus is not. At least, if one takes Archangels simplistic view of the Constitution. Whether the protection the Constitution affords can be stripped is somewhat moot. There are no clash of rights within the Constitution. Aye, but re: abortion only one of those has any relevance. Namely, the State's interest in preserving liberty. However, speaking solely of what the Constitution protects, obviously liberty is the more important right in this issue than life. Ultimately, and obviously, Archangels simplistic view of the Constitution is false and there are additional checks before a State can violate certain liberties but this does illustrate some interesting points.
